name: Sumatran Tiger
description: The smallest subspecies of tiger, it boasts a vibrant golden coloration with dense, narrow stripes. Males are distinguished by striking whitish facial whiskers.
food_note: Medium to large vertebrates up to the size of a deer
proportions: Body length 1.4 m; tail length 60 cm; shoulder height 80 cm; weight 65 kg
reproduction: Females are pregnant for 102–105 days, giving birth to 2–4 cubs.
attractions: The Sumatran tiger is closely tied to continuous tropical forests and avoids areas heavily impacted by human activity. It lives a solitary, secretive life. Requiring a relatively large territory, tiger density in any given area remains low.
projects_note: Listed as critically endangered on the IUCN Red List, its wild population does not exceed 680 individuals and is fragmented into subpopulations of up to 50 tigers each.
breeding: The Sumatran tiger is a traditional species at Prague Zoo. The first female arrived in 1958, though serious breeding began in the 1960s. The pair Maje (arrived 1967) and Radúz 2 (arrived 1966) produced the zoo’s first two cubs in 1971—males Adam and Ali. A Rotterdam pair, Mahulena 2 and Gabriel (arrived 1968), raised a female cub, Balige, in 1973. By 2013, nine more cubs had been bred at the zoo.
